title: Modeling a Periodic Context-Tire, Part C

content.description:
The tire of a car has a radius of <math alttext="9" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mn>9</mn> </math> inches, and a person rolls the tire forward at a constant rate on level ground, as shown in the figure. Point <math alttext="W" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>W</mi></math> on the edge of the tire touches the ground at time <math alttext="1 half" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mfrac> <mn>1</mn> <mn>2</mn> </mfrac> </math> second. The tire completes a full rotation, and the next time <math alttext="W" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>W</mi> </math> touches the ground is at time <math alttext="t equals 5 over 2" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mfrac> <mn>5</mn> <mn>2</mn> </mfrac> </math> seconds. The maximum height of <math alttext="W" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>W</mi></math> above the ground is <math alttext="18" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>18</mn></math> inches. As the tire rolls, the height of <math alttext="W" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>W</mi></math> above the ground periodically increases and decreases.

The sinusoidal function <math alttext="h" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>h</mi></math> models the height of point <math alttext="W" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>W</mi></math> above the ground, in inches, as a function of time <math alttext="t" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi></math>, in seconds.

(i) On the interval <math alttext="open parentheses t subscript 1 comma t subscript 2 close parentheses"> <mfenced> <mrow> <msub> <mi>t</mi> <mn>1</mn> </msub> <mo>,</mo> <msub> <mi>t</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> </mrow> </mfenced> </math>, which of the following is true about <math alttext="h"> <mi>h</mi> </math>?

<math alttext="h"> <mi>h</mi> </math> is positive and increasing.

<math alttext="h"> <mi>h</mi> </math> is positive and decreasing.
